I hope Americans who brushed off the #MuellerReport listen (specifically to hear about 10 obstruction instances).

All of us, as Members of Congress, must honor our oath to hold the executive branch accountable. It's our duty to follow the facts so we can protect our democracy. https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1143690677039091717 …
Tragic https://twitter.com/AP/status/1143620181639475202 …
I remain in favor of the impeachment process. The future of our country is at stake. No one is above the law.

Even before all of these actions took place or were documented, I voted to advance @RepAlGreen’s impeachment resolution in 2017 because I know that, as a co-equal branch of government, it is Congress' obligation to hold the executive branch accountable. We took an oath to act.

🔟Trump's changing behavior toward Michael Cohen.

The Mueller report described how Trump’s conduct toward Cohen, a fmr Trump Org exec, changed from praise to castigation after Cohen began cooperating with prosecutors.

9⃣Trump pressuring possible witnesses, including Flynn & Manafort.

Trump’s team asked fmr national security adviser Michael Flynn for a “heads up” on information & commended fmr campaign manager Paul Manafort for not “flipping."

8⃣Trump trying to get Sessions to take back control of the Mueller investigation.

The Mueller report says there’s evidence that one purpose of Trump asking Sessions to stop being recused between July-Dec 2017 was so Sessions would restrict the scope of the investigation.

7⃣Trump trying to have Sessions curtail the Mueller investigation.

Trump told adviser Corey Lewandowski to have then-AG Sessions publicly announce the Mueller investigation was “very unfair” & have Sessions tell Mueller to limit future investigations in election meddling.
6⃣Trump trying to stop then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions from recusing himself from the Russia investigation in the first place.

5⃣Trump telling McGahn to deny that he had wanted Mueller removed.

Trump told then-WH counsel McGahn to “correct” a New York Times story that reported Trump had earlier instructed McGahn to fire special counsel Mueller.

4⃣Trump attempting to stop the public from seeing evidence.

Trump directed aides not to publicly disclose the emails that set up the Trump Tower meeting (involving Russia providing information on Hillary Clinton) & Trump edited a related press statement for Donald Trump Jr.

3⃣Trump trying to remove Special Counsel Mueller after he was appointed.

Trump reacted to news of Mueller’s appointment by telling advisers that it was “the end of his presidency.” Trump even called then-WH counsel McGahn & directed him to have Mueller removed. McGahn refused.

2⃣The firing of FBI Director James Comey.

The Mueller report says “substantial evidence” indicates Trump’s decision to fire was the result of Comey's unwillingness to say publicly that Trump was not personally under investigation.

1⃣Trump pressuring then-FBI Director James Comey to end the probe of then-national security adviser Michael Flynn.

Trump: “I hope you can see your way to letting this go.”

THREAD: We have a President who obstructs, blocks & limits access.

At every turn, the administration ignores subpoenas & instructs officials not to communicate with Congress—it's reprehensible.

Here are 🔟obstruction counts from Federal Prosecutor & Special Counsel Mueller...

Our military has operated without a Defense secretary since December & I encourage Pres. Trump to permanently nominate someone to fill the position. Uncertainty makes us less safe.

Congratulations to @USArmy Sec. Esper on new role as Acting Sec. of @DeptofDefense.
 
I’ve gotten to know Sec. Esper as Chair of TAL Subcommittee & I look forward to working together in a new capacity.

Appropriate visit to @Amazon in West Deptford for their grand opening on the day when we hit the longest record for failure to increase the fed min wage. Amazon is leading by example — paying $15 an hour minimum.

#RaiseTheWage #FightFor15 #ForThePeople @fightfor15 @EdLaborCmte pic.twitter.com/XHvnVUDOsX

Sometimes it's not good to break records...

Today’s minimum wage workers have less buying power than they did in the 1960s. 🤦🏻‍♂️

We must #RaiseTheWage! pic.twitter.com/y6KnAPRVvQ

DISAPPOINTING NEW RECORD: It's been 3,615 days since the minimum wage increased.

That's the longest since we first created a min. wage to ensure fairness for workers in 1938.

It's well-past time to #RAISETHEWAGE!
